Anyone Who Uses Terminal on MacOS, Should Edit Their .bash_profile

  • Shell
  • Terminal
Back to posts /
Twitter Facebook Google+
19 Dec 2016

Everyone who uses terminal for anything, should know about .bash_profile. If you happen to be someone who didn‚Äôt even know a .bash_profile existed, you‚Äôve come to the right place. Your .bash_profile is a file that basically allows you to customize your terminal.

Your hidden .bash_profile is usually found in the default home directory:

cd ~/.bash_profile

I have atom text editor installed, so I can open .bash_profile with:

$ atom ~/.bash_profile

Although I‚Äôm not a huge fan, you can edit directly from terminal instead of installing atom with:

$ nano ~/.bash_profile

Change Terminal Prompt Display

If you‚Äôd no longer want to display you username as your terminal prompt and want it to now say ‚ÄúHacker‚Äù instead, add this to your .bash_profile:

PS1 = "Hacker "

Similarly you can even drag and drop an emoji in-between the quotation and your terminal prompt will display it:

PS1 = "Hacker üíÄ "

You can add ‚Äú\W‚Äù or ‚Äú\w‚Äù to your PS1. Where typing uppercase ‚Äú\w‚Äù shows the whole working directory and lowercase ‚Äú\W‚Äù adds only the current working directory to your terminal prompt, if you‚Äôd still like those displayed:

PS1 = "Hacker üíÄ \w"

You can save and refresh these changes from terminal with following command:

$ source ~/.bash_profile

Adding an Alias Shortcut

Adding an alias is awesome. You can use an alias from any place by simply typing the alias and it‚Äôll do the requested command. For example if you had a directory that you use often:

~/some_path/folder

You can then just add the following to the .bash_profile:

alias hack="cd ~/some_path/folder"

Save and refresh:

$ source ~/.bash_profile

And now every time you type the alias in terminal, you‚Äôll cd into that directory:

$ hack
